Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification brought pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, which authorizes the Probate and Family Court to modify judgments relating to custody when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred, and such modification is in the best interests of the child.

G. L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has continuing jurisdiction under G. L. c. 208, § 28 and G. L. c. 215, § 6 to modify its prior orders based on changes affecting the welfare of the minor child.

G. L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G. L. c. 208, § 28; G. L. c. 209C, § 20)

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify an existing custody order “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a modification of custody requires a material and substantial change in circumstances and that such modification must serve the best interests of the child. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. In the provided text, the court does not discuss the standard for *modification* of an existing custody order, nor does it articulate the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement. While it refers generally to considering the child’s best interests, it does not clearly establish the specific modification standard attributed to it in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child… [C]ourts [must] make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect…”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a modification of custody requires a material and substantial change in circumstances and that such modification must serve the best interests of the child. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, in a joint physical custody context. The opinion discusses that relocation (and resulting modification of parenting plans) is governed by the children’s best interests and, by reference to the ALI Principles, notes that relocation can constitute a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not clearly state the general Massachusetts rule that a modification of custody requires a material and substantial change in circumstances plus a best-interests analysis. That proposition is more squarely grounded in other cases such as Custody of Vaughn; Mason adds nuance for relocation with joint custody but is not the core authority for the stated rule.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002) ... state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]...
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests . . . .”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Following eight days of trial, the major portion of which was devoted to the question of custody, the judge concluded that, even though the wife ‘may be irrational in perceiving joint custody as a vehicle whereby her husband can continue to impose his will upon her,’ in the instant circumstances joint custody would be entirely inappropriate and injurious to the children… The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The best interests standard is paramount in custody determinations. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that, under the Massachusetts removal statute, the words “upon cause shown” mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and describes the best interests of the child as the central and paramount concern. The court’s analysis of custody and removal repeatedly frames the inquiry in terms of the children’s best interests, confirming that this standard is paramount in such custody-related determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… [t]he words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent…’”}

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The best interests standard is paramount in custody determinations. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody cases “the governing principle” and “dominating rule” is the welfare of the child, and that the child’s happiness and welfare must be the “controlling consideration.” This is functionally equivalent to the modern articulation that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody determinations, and the court applies that standard in affirming the custody award.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: When a parent’s physical capacity endangers or unduly burdens the child, courts have modified custody to protect the child’s welfare. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); M.P.M. v. D.M., 442 Mass. 39 (2004).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a parent’s "physical capacity" endangering or burdening the child, nor does it involve a modification of custody based on such physical limitations. The custody allocation turns on best-interests factors like work schedules, use of daycare, and relative attentiveness to medical and daily needs, but there is no finding that either parent’s physical capacity posed a risk to the child. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child. This conclusion was based, in turn, on a number of findings, including, inter alia, that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs...; that the father...works long hours, often involving overtime, resulting in Kali’s spending most of her time during the week in day care; that the mother has more flexible hours and is able to spend more time with Kali during the weekdays; [and] that the mother is more “attuned” to Kali’s medical, educational, and daily needs.

M.P.M. v. D.M., 442 Mass. 39 (2004).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal sentencing/ineffective assistance case about a juvenile homicide offender and the timeliness of a motion to revise or revoke sentence. It does not concern child custody, parental fitness, or the effect of a parent’s physical capacity on a child’s welfare. Therefore it cannot support the proposition about modifying custody based on a parent’s physical capacity and appears to be a miscitation in that context.
M.P.M. v. D.M., 442 Mass. 39 (2004).relevant_excerpt: We therefore conclude that there was no ineffective assistance of counsel in connection with any potential motion to revise or revoke the defendant’s sentence, and thus no basis on which the defendant could arguably be excused from the sixty-day time limit in which to file such a motion. Accordingly, we vacate the allowance of the defendant’s motion to revise or revoke his sentence, vacate the judge’s order sentencing the defendant to from fifteen years to fifteen years and one day, and reinstate the defendant’s original sentence.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The child’s forced role as caretaker is contrary to her developmental needs and the policy against parentification. See Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), cert. denied, 526 U.S. 1034 (1999).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any child being placed in a forced caretaker role, nor does it use or develop a doctrine or policy against 'parentification.' Its analysis focuses on weighing two adoption placements based on best interests, stability, developmental needs, and attachments, without framing any concern as the child improperly acting as caretaker for a parent or sibling. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about a child’s forced caretaker role being contrary to developmental needs and a policy against parentification.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.... That Hugo has “done well” in his foster home... is not reason enough to deny him the opportunity to do his very best, even if that opportunity is untested.

cert. denied, 526 U.S. 1034 (1999).proposition: See Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), cert. denied, 526 U.S. 1034 (1999).

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation ‘in a manner other than as directed by the original order’ but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order.”

Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 392 Mass. 71.proposition: The Plaintiff’s proposal serves the purposes of both stability and safety, as emphasized in Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 392 Mass. 719 (1984), and Bluhm v. Bluhm, 93 Mass. App. Ct. 121 (2018).
Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 392 Mass. 71.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the standards for removing a child from parental custody and terminating visitation—requiring findings of current parental unfitness and specific findings that visitation will harm the child. While it mentions that a child’s interests are generally best served in the “stable, continuous environment of his own family,” it does not frame a legal principle that a particular party’s proposal must serve both “stability and safety” in the way the proposition suggests. The case is about evidentiary and procedural safeguards, not an articulated balancing test of stability and safety supporting a given custodial proposal.
Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 392 Mass. 71.relevant_excerpt: “Because the interest of the child is thought to be best served in the stable, continuous environment of his own family, . . . State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection… A judge is required to exercise utmost care in custody proceedings and must make ‘specific and detailed findings demonstrating that close attention has been given the evidence and that the necessity of removing the child from his or her parents has been persuasively shown.’”

Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).proposition: Public policy favors fostering a stable and nurturing environment for children consistent with a parent’s ability to provide safe care. See Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the exact phrasing of the proposition, but its reasoning clearly reflects the same policy. The court repeatedly emphasizes that the child’s best interests are paramount over parental rights, noting the Commonwealth’s policy to strengthen family life but to provide substitute care when necessary to ensure a child’s health and development, and it highlights the nurturing and stability provided by the foster/adoptive home. This aligns with the idea that public policy favors a stable, nurturing environment consistent with a parent’s ability to provide safe care.
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 119, § 1, declares it to be the “policy of this commonwealth to direct its efforts, first, to the strengthening and encouragement of family life for the care and protection of children; to assist and encourage the use by any family of all available resources to this end; and to provide substitute care of children only when the family itself or the resources available to the family are unable to provide the necessary care and protection to insure the rights of any child to sound health and normal physical, mental, spiritual and moral development.” … While courts protect the rights of parents, “the parents’ rights are secondary to the child’s best interests and ... the proper focus of termination proceedings is the welfare of the child.”
